Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of LA-ICP-QQQ-MS equipment for in situ trace element and isotopic research and training at the University of Maine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will enable the University of Maine to acquire a mass spectrometer for geoscientists to investigate Earth system processes, such as crustal subduction and paleoclimate. The instrument is capable of measuring minute concentrations of elements over distances the thickness of a human hair to learn how rocks are cycled deep into the earth and then back to the surface as magma. The mass spectrometer adds the dimension of time by obtaining the ages of rocks at time scales ranging from days to billions of years. The versatile analytical capability of the mass spectrometer is used in the study of past climates and ocean conditions by making the same type of measurements in rocks and fossils from places as diverse as beneath oceans and in caves. The mass spectrometer will serve as a regional facility, promoting and stimulating collaborations at colleges throughout the state of Maine.

The acquisition of a laser-ablation inductively-coupled-plasma triple-quad mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-QQQ-MS) by the University of Maine will further research into Earth system processes that cut across the geosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere, The state-of-the-art instrument will measure trace element and isotopic data at the micro-scale to examine the geologic archive, such as daily growth bands in foraminifer shells, or zones within single zircon crystals spanning billions of years of Earth history. Diffusion and geodynamical modeling integrate the geochemical data with field observations whose spatial and temporal scales range from microns to kilometers and days to billions of years. These data will enhance understanding of tectonic processes and terrestrial and marine paleoclimate records. The research projects include petrology and geochemical studies of rocks that are the origin of subduction-zone magmas and the reconstruction of past climate and ocean conditions. The mass spectrometer will provide extensive training and research opportunities and enhance the analytical and technological literacy for a diverse group of students from a variety of STEM disciplines at the University of Maine and a number of other colleges in the state of Maine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was used to establish a laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) facility at the University of Maine (https://umaine.edu/earthclimate/facilities/magiclaser/). The instrumentation was installed in the new MicroAnalytical Geochemistry and Isotope Characterization Laboratory, or MAGIC Lab. This facility is the first of its kind in the state of Maine, and serves the University of Maine system, including the flagship campus in Orono where the instrumentation is housed, and the branch campuses of the university across the state. The MAGIC Lab also serves the colleges of Maine (such as Bates, Bowdoin, and Colby) and the Maine Geological Survey. Access is open to all who are interested in doing analyses worldwide.

The instrumentation in the MAGIC lab consists of an ESI NWR193UC laser ablation system coupled with an Agilent 8900 ICP-MS/MS. This instrumentation is used to sample solid materials in situ at very small spatial scales for geochemical analysis. For instance, most analyses are done with laser spot sizes that are less than 50 micrometers in diameter, or less than half of the thickness of a human hair. Many of the analyses that are done in the lab involve looking at trace metals in minerals and biominerals, in order to determine the temperature of the formation of rocks, or to determine proxies for paleo ocean temperatures. Many analyses are also done for geochronology, in order to determine the time at which different geological processes have taken place. One of most exciting aspects of this instrumentation is the collision/reaction cell, which allows us to isolate specific isobaric interferences and use dating systems, such as Rb-Sr, that are typically unattainable on quadrupole machines.

Instrumentation in the MAGIC Lab has been integrated in the undergraduate and graduate curricula of the School of Earth and Climate Sciences at the University of Maine. Both graduate and undergraduate students have been trained to use the instrumentation, and data have been incorporated into three undergraduate theses, two M.S. theses, and two Ph.D. dissertations currently in progress. The award has resulted in seven abstracts presented at conferences regionally, nationally, and internationally, including three poster presentations with undergraduate students as first author. PI Cruz-Uribe also gave an invited oral presentation on the method development undertaken in the MAGIC Lab at a workshop at the Goldschmidt Conference in 2019 in Barcelona, Spain. A listserve for ICP-MS/MS users was also created as part of this project and is hosted by the University of Maine (http://lists.maine.edu/cgi/wa?A0=ICP-MS-MS).
